children.subject: I head EECS 127 is really important to ML research as well, and I can potentially take it instead of 188 in the fall. But I also want to secure an internship for summer next year, will 188 give me a better shot at SWE/AI internships if ML internships are too hard to get?
I found 189  more useful for internships. 188 was more just general knowledge like surface level about many areas. Nothing really deep enough for interviews

<md>For ML research I'd recommend taking EECS 126, CS 188, and EECS 127. Ditch CS 170, I've not found it useful at all in ML research. I could be biased because I knew most of the CS 170 syllabus before going into the class, but I've almost never experienced hardcore 170 topics like streaming or NP hardness showing up in ML literature or even my own research. Of course, you will probably experience stuff like greedy algorithms and DP (Q learning is just fancy DP), but you can teach this to yourself by reading the DPV textbook.</md>

<md>Also generally ML internships would be hard to get without prior ML experience, so anything you can get you should take. I agree with Gear in that 189 helps more. But I would NOT take 189 with neither 126 nor 127.</md>
for shewchuks you don't need 126 or 127. you just need cs 70 and the ability to self learn vector calculus

<md>If you want to do well in shewchuks 189 then you probably want one or the other at least. You will not only have a more relaxed time but you will also probably learn more. Unless you're willing to put the hours into learning from ISL and ESL, you probably want either 127 or 126 at least and preferably both</md>

if i self learned over winter break with a very average understanding of ee16a/16b(took these freshman year and got B-) and cs70 as my background could i still survive 189 w shewchuk? Don't have time in my schedule to take ee127 or ee126.

I found that it took very little to self-study coming from a very little math background. If you pick things up fast the discussions and resources they link should make it more than possible. I wouldn't advise taking a class just to prep for another when that time could be better spent taking something you can enjoy. For schewchuks version you don't need any probability past 70 and 127 will help to solve the optima stuff but not to the degree that it must be taken before. I took the class with a former 127 TA and they felt that 127 was way overkill so take it if you are interested in the material not for 189 prep. You should definitely get at least a B- if you understand like least squares and the ML parts of 16B along with the probability of 70

<md>If you wish to get a B- in 189, then that sounds fine. If you wish to get an A- or better while trying to get a deeper understanding of the subject (outside of what lectures teach), then it's best to take 126/127. Shewchuk's lectures have very little mathematical rigor. He rarely goes over proofs or covers deep mathematical intuition behind concepts. If you want to understand the material well, then you should be able to fill in these gaps on your own. For many people, Shewchuk's lectures trick them into thinking they understand the concepts when in reality they really don't know how the mathematical formulations are created. If you want to ask the question "what?" while doing 189, you don't need 126/127. If you want to ask the question "why?", it's probably best to take one of those two classes at least. If you want to learn concepts at a high level and don't care about deeper understanding (imo you probably want deeper understanding if you're doing ML research), then 70 probability alongside 16ab linear algebra is sufficient</md>
<md>106a is not too connected to ML (besides the robotics related parts). 188 is more about general AI topics. 126 is very important for ML research</md>

If you take 170, 126, and 127 in the fall, that will best set you up for 189 in the spring (which you could take alongside 188 or something else), but that fall schedule would be pretty hard. Alternatively you could do 170, 126, and 188 in the fall and 189 and 127 in the spring, which should balance out the work a bit and not detract too much (189 and 127 concurrently is still pretty good for understanding).

I would take 188, it's a cool class even if it's not the most useful for ML internships.

if you want ML 189 is a near requirement. Skip 188 if you need to fit it in as it more so intro to AI. If you want to work in ML they're gonna ask you a lot of the theory to make sure you can understand and implement stuff which is what 189 prepares you for.
<md>If you want the highest chance at an internship, then take CS 170, CS 162, and CS 189. Will you have a good time? Probably not. Will you most likely get an internship of some sort? Probably.</md>

OP here, I think my main goal is to secure either an SWE or ML (though chances are small) internship for next summer. Will taking CS 170, 188, EECS 126 be enough to reach that goal? Should I consider taking 186 since it's more related to SWE?

history.content: After taking Data 100 and 16B, I found myself interested in ML topics, and I am interested in applying for ML-related research and internships in the fall and summer. I'm also planning to do the 4th Year Master's program, which I will be applying to in fall 2022. My current plan for fall 2021 is to take CS 170 and 2 out of CS 188, EECS 126 and EECS 106A. I know 188 and 126 are probably more relevant to ML and will prepare me for 189 in spring 2022. However, EECS C106A is only offered in the fall and I am not sure whether it will help me with research or a career in ML. Can someone who has taken 188, 126 and/or 106A provide some input and advice?
history.subject: Fall Course Advice (ML-oriented)
